data.question: Can you provide practice problems on multiplying two matrices?

docs.title: 674dcdb4b00b977d048c931b
docs.text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

docs.title: 674dcde1b00b977d048c9352
docs.text: Two outlets of a coffee chain sell three different types of coffee: espresso, flat white and mocha. The table shows the number of cups of each type of coffee sold on a particular day. Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).

docs.title: 674dce0fb00b977d048c9395

By using matrix multiplication, calculate the total amount of money the dance school earns for this 10-week block of sessions.

Correct your answer to the nearest cent.

data.output:
A food truck serves three types of meals: burgers, tacos, and salads. The following table shows the number of each type of meal sold on two different days:\\
\[
\begin{array}{ccc}
\text{Day} & \text{Burgers} & \text{Tacos} & \text{Salads} \\
\hline
\text{Monday} & 200 & 150 & 80 \\
\text{Tuesday} & 180 & 160 & 100 \\
\end{array}
\]
\newline
The cost of each meal is represented by the vector \( C = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ 3 \\ 6 \end{pmatrix} \), where the costs are in dollars for a burger, taco, and salad, respectively.\\
(i) Write the matrix \( M \) that represents the number of meals sold on Monday and Tuesday.\\
(ii) Find the matrix \( R = MC \).\\
(iii) Explain what each element of matrix \( R \) represents.\\
(iv) Calculate the total revenue generated from the sales on both days.

A theme park offers three types of passes: daily, weekly, and monthly. The table below shows the number of each type of pass sold over two days.\[ \text{\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline & \text{Daily} & \text{Weekly} & \text{Monthly} \\ \hline \text{Saturday} & 120 & 85 & 30 \\ \hline \text{Sunday} & 110 & 95 & 25 \\ \hline \end{array}} \] This information can be represented by the matrix \( X = \begin{pmatrix} 120 & 85 & 30 \\ 110 & 95 & 25 \end{pmatrix} \). 

The prices for each type of pass are represented by the matrix \( Y = \begin{pmatrix} 20 \\ 45 \\ 100 \end{pmatrix} \), where 20, 45, and 100 represent the prices in dollars for a daily, weekly, and monthly pass, respectively. 

(i) Calculate the matrix \( Z = XY \).
(ii) Explain what each element of matrix \( Z \) represents.
(iii) Determine the total revenue collected from the sales of passes over the weekend.

data.output:
A school sells tickets to a carnival at $45 for adults, $30 for students, and $15 for children. On a particular weekend, there were 200 adults, 320 students, and 150 children on Saturday, and 220 adults, 310 students, and 140 children on Sunday. The number of visitors can be represented by the matrix \( W = \begin{pmatrix} 200 & 320 & 150 \\ 220 & 310 & 140 \end{pmatrix} \). 

(i) Write a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix, \( Q \), to represent the price of these tickets. 

(ii) Find the matrix \( S = WQ \). 

(iii) What does the result of the matrix \( S \) represent? 

(iv) Calculate the total revenue collected from ticket sales for the weekend.

data.output:
A theater has three types of movie tickets: adult, child, and senior. On a given day, Theater 1 sold 120 adult tickets, 100 child tickets, and 30 senior tickets. Theater 2 sold \(x\) adult tickets, \(x + 10\) child tickets, and 20 senior tickets. The number of tickets sold can be represented by the matrix:
$$M = \begin{pmatrix} 120 & 100 & 30 \\ x & x+10 & 20 \end{pmatrix}$$

The prices for each ticket type are as follows: adult tickets are $12, child tickets are $8, and senior tickets are $5. Let the price matrix be represented as:
$$N = \begin{pmatrix} 12 \\ 8 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}$$

(a) Write the expression for the matrix product \(S = MN\).
(b) If Theater 2 collected $210 more than Theater 1, find the value of \(x\).

**[5 marks]**

At a community sports festival, tickets for events are sold as follows: $40 for adults, $25 for teenagers, and $15 for children. On Friday, 120 adults, 200 teenagers, and 70 children attended the events. On Saturday, 150 adults, 230 teenagers, and 80 children attended. Representing the attendance using the matrix \( A = \begin{pmatrix} 120 & 200 & 70 \\ 150 & 230 & 80 \end{pmatrix} \), do the following:

(i) Write a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix \( P \) to represent the price of the tickets.

(ii) Compute the matrix \( T = AP \).

(iii) Explain what each element of the matrix \( T \) represents.

(iv) Calculate the total revenue collected from the ticket sales over the two days.

docs.text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).
